text:
The name Intramuros comes from the Latin words “intra,” meaning “within” and “muros,” meaning “walls.” Intramuros is located on the southern bank of the Pasig River, near the river’s mouth. Laid out as an irregular pentagon with an area of 0.67 sq km, Intramuros is enclosed by a 3.7-km-long wall. It is also known as Ciudad Murada or the Walled City.

Intramuros was established in 1571. This was the center of Spanish colonial government, the civil, ecclesiastical, educational, economic, and cultural center of the Philippines for more than three centuries. It was also a residential area for Spanish colonists. Other ethnic groups, like the Chinese and the Tagalog, lived outside the walled city.

 

The Intramuros Heritage Area is comprised of two parts: a military area, Fort Santiago, and a civilian area, the Spanish ciudad or city of Manila. Fort Santiago occupies the northwestern apex of the walled city, while the rest comprises the ciudad.

Intramuros was laid out as a grid of streets with open and green spaces called plazas and spaces for a variety of buildings, following the principles of Renaissance urban planning as codified in the 1573 Laws of the Indies.

Streets. The principal streets, which defined the city plan, runs northwest to southeast. These streets are Calle Real del Palacio and Calle (Real del) Parian, which set the grid layout of the city. Renaissance town planners drew inspiration from the classical era: Calle Real del Palacio was analogous to classical Rome’s cardo and Calle Parian was analogous to the decumanus. Calle Real, now Gen Luna, was originally named for the governor general’s palace, Palacio del Gobernador, and later renamed to honor Gen Antonio Luna, brother of the painter Juan Luna and an officer of the revolutionary army against Spain.

Calle (Real del) Parian was initially called Parian because it led to the Parian gate and ravelin. The street runs perpendicular to Real del Palacio and crosses it, three blocks south of the Manila Cathedral and in front of San Agustin Monastery. Called Real after 1780, when Puerta Real at the end of Calle Real was closed as a precaution against a siege, Real del Parian became the ceremonial street through which the carriages of the governor-general and the archbishop of Manila passed. Calle Parian led to the business district and Chinese enclave outside Intramuros located north and east, at the areas presently occupied by the Central Post Office, the Metropolitan Theater, the LRT Central Station, and the Arroceros Forest Park.

Within the walls, a perimeter road follows the line of the walls. Its name varies depending on where it runs. It is called Muralla at its northeastern section. At the southwestern section it is called Fundición (foundry) because it passes a military foundry at the Baluarte de San Diego, as depicted in 18th century maps. The length of the perimeter road that runs parallel to the seaside flank of the city walls, passing by Santa Lucia gate, became known as Santa Lucia.

These secondary roads run on the city’s northwest-southeast axis: Arzobispo was named for the archbishop’s palace, which was located along this street. The site of the archbishop’s palace is now occupied by the Archdiocese of Manila’s archbishop’s residence and chancery. The north end of Arzobispo was named Audiencia because it passed by the building of the Real Audiencia. Cabildo was named after the city council or cabildo, which had its session hall along the street. The session hall was also called Ayuntamiento or city hall. The 19th-century cabildo was destroyed during World War II and has recently been restored.

Magallanes is named after Ferdinand Magellan. Solana, formerly known as Fonda, is probably named in honor of Governor Urbiztondo, the Marques de la Solana. Legazpi/San Juan de Dios St honors Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, who was the founder of Spanish Manila and first governor general of the Philippines. Its southeastern section was named after the hospital run by the Brothers of San Juan de Dios. The street was formerly known as Bomba, which can mean either pump or bomb.

Escuela is named after an unknown school. Letran, formerly Cerrada, is named after Colegio de San Juan de Letrán.

These are the roads that run perpendicular to the northwest and southeast axis of the city: Almacenes, presently Maestranza, is a short stretch of road that continues the perimeter road Muralla, near Plaza Militar. It is named for the real almacenes or the royal storehouses that stood inside and outside the walls, beside the Pasig River. The street led to a small gate called Almacenes that opened to the Pasig. The storehouses expanded to the casamata or vaulted chambers of the Maestranza wall, the thickest part of the Intramuros curtain wall. Maestranza has been restored, after it was deliberately demolished around 1905 to allow easy access to the wharfs along the Pasig.

Santa Clara is named after the Real Monasterio de Santa Clara, a convent of contemplative Franciscan nuns, founded by Sor Geronima Asuncion in 1621. Aduana, referred to the Aduana or Custom house at the northeastern end of the street, built in the neoclassical style of the 19th century. The Aduana building also housed the Intendencia or city management office and was the alternate name given to the building. The street is presently known as Andres Soriano Jr, after the industrialist and entrepreneur who founded San Miguel Corporation.

Postigo, formerly Cruzadas (Crusades), led to the postigo or postern gate and connects with Calle Santo Tomas. It was through this road and gate that Dr Jose P. Rizal passed on the way to his execution in Bagumbayan on 30 Dec 1896. Santo Tomas, the eastern end of Postigo, terminated at the Universidad de Santo Tomas.

Beaterio is named after the Beaterio de Santa Catalina. Anda honors Simon de Anda who organized the resistance during the British occupation of Manila (1762-64) and functioned as acting governor-general, while on exile in Bulacan. San Francisco is named after the Franciscan convent and church. Santa Potenciana is named after the patroness of Manila and a college for girls dedicated to her; the western end of this street is called San Agustin.

Novales is named after Capitan Andres Novales. Victoria is named after the 85-ton vessel used by Sebastian Elcano to circumnavigate the globe. Gen Douglas MacArthur built his headquarters at the western end of Victoria, giving it the address No 1 Victoria.

San Jose, named after the Colegio de San Jose, disappeared from the map, when the Jesuits petitioned the city to close the street and incorporate it as part of two adjacent compounds owned by the Jesuits. This made access to and from the Colegio de San Ignacio and Colegio de San Jose more convenient.

Maleçon was a road built outside the walls, along the shore, and beyond the moat beginning at the mouth of the Pasig, and ending in a half-moon turn called Luneta. Part of the road has become Bonifacio Drive and Padre Burgos Ave.

Plazas. Integral to the Renaissance-inspired colonial plans were plazas. These served as green areas for the city and as outdoor meeting places. The two largest plazas were: Plaza Militar, later called Plaza Moriones, and the Plaza Mayor. Located in front and southeast of Fort Santiago, Plaza Militar was used for military drills. Its perimeter was defined by the walls of the city and Almacenes or the royal storehouses and the Audiencia building. Inside Fort Santiago was Plaza de Armas, used for assembling troops as they changed guards for the walls of the fort and city.

Plaza Mayor stood in front of the Manila Cathedral. Around it were the most important buildings of the colonial era, the Cathedral, the Palacio del Gobernador, the Ayuntamiento, and the Real Audiencia. In 1824, a monument to Carlos IV was erected in the plaza to honor him for sending vaccines to control the spread of cholera in the 19th century. Bullfights and theatrical productions were held at the Plaza Mayor on several occasions. Plaza Mayor was renamed Plaza Roma to honor Pope Paul VI on his visit to the Philippines in 1970.

Other minor plazas were located in front or near the principal buildings, like churches and educational institutions. Universidad de Santo Tomas (UST) had its own small plaza, where the statue honoring Abp Miguel de Benavides, founder of the Santo Tomas, used to stand. The statue is now in the Sampaloc campus of UST. Plaza Sampalucan, also known as Plaza de Santa Isabel, is presently the site of Memorare, a memorial to Intramuros’s war victims.

Fortification. Fuerza de Santiago or Fort Santiago was the military fortification attached to the walled city. Built at the site of Rajah Sulayman’s fortified palisade, the site was captured by the invading troops led by Miguel Lopez de Legazpi in 1571.

 

Intramuros’s fortifications consisted of walls, bastiones, and their variations: the falsabraga, plataforma, and media naranja. The walls connecting the bastions are called cortina or curtain wall. On the walls are parapets, a walkway for sentries, and the cylindrical garita or guardhouse used in inclement weather. Within the walls are barracks, officers’s quarters, jail and dungeon, and storehouses. Outside the walls and protecting its perimeter was a moat and outer defenses called fortin, small independent forts, ravelin that protected the entrances, and luneta that helped reinforce the corners of the bastions.

The principal parts of Fort Santiago are Falsabraga de Santa Barbara, named after the patroness of the artillery corps. It was probably built ca 1739. Near it is the Plataforma de Santa Barbara, a level area to mount artillery and probably part of the oldest section of Fort Santiago. Adjacent to Santa Barbara is the Falsabraga Media Naranja. It is called media naranja because its plan is a semicircle, or picturesquely, half an orange.

Other bastions are: Medio Bastion de San Francisco, called medio bastion because it lacks a full flank; Baluartillo (Bastion) de San Francisco, named after San Francisco de Asis, founder of the Franciscan order.

Outside the wall, facing the sea and near the Baluartillo de San Francisco is the Reducto (Fortín) de San Francisco, an independent outer fortification, connected to the main walls by a walkway.

Bastion Hererias Maestranza is named after two adjacent structures: Hererias or the royal foundry and the Maestranza or royal armory, both located beside Plaza Militar. Both structures are outside the south wall of Fort Santiago. No remains stand above ground, but foundations have been uncovered by archaeologists. Also in the area is Bastion de San Lorenzo which is named after San Lorenzo Martir.

The city of Manila, the non-military part, was separated from Fort Santiago by a gate and a moat in front of it. From the 18th century, a stone bridge connected the Fort with the city. The bridge was positioned to the western side of Fort Santiago’s entrance.

City Fortification. Baluartillo de San Juan or small bastion of San Juan is named after San Juan Bautista on whose feast day, 24 Jun 1571, the City of Manila was founded. Bastion de San Jose is named after San Jose, the foster father of Jesus. The Reducto (Fortín) de San Pedro is named after San Pedro Apostol—this is an independent outer fortification and connected to the main walls by a walkway.

Bastion de San Diego, also known as Santiago, is built around an older fortification erected by Fr Antonio Sedeño in the late 16th century. It is named Nuestra Señora de Guia. Presently, the bastion and its lower section, the site of the Fundicion or foundry, is a garden park.

Bastión Plano de Santa Isabel is named after Santa Isabel, the cousin of the Virgin Mary. Baluartillo de San Eugenio is named after San Eugenio, who was the Pope from 654 to 657. Revellin de la Puerta Real de Bagumbayan is an outer fortification built to protect the Royal gate built after the British occupation of Manila from 1762 to 1764. The ravelin housed an aquarium in the 20th century. The ravelin faced the native settlement of Bagumbayan, whose site is now occupied by Luneta Park. Bagumbayan was so named because the Tagalog who were eased out of the area occupied by Intramuros built a new village (literally, bagong bayan) outside the southern perimeter of the walled city. It had its own parish church built and administered by the Recollects. The church was ordered demolished after the British occupation because attackers of the walled city could use it as a defensive position during a siege, which was what the British did.

Bastion de San Andres is named after San Andres, proclaimed patron of Manila, after the attack by the Chinese Limahong in 1574 was successfully repulsed on the feast of San Andres on 30 Nov. San Andres is the brother of San Pedro.

Revellin de Recoletos is an outer defense to protect the gate near the church of the Recollects. It is presently restored and reused by Escuela Taller, a school that trains out of school youths in restoration techniques and preserves the building tradition of the colonial era. Bastion de San Francisco de Dilao is named as such because it faced the district of Dilao, a Japanese enclave, east of the walls. The district was transferred to Paco and the residences were demolished after the British left Manila in 1764. Revellin de Parian protected the gate with the same name and led to the Parian, the Chinese district outside the walls. Bastion de San Gabriel is named after the Archangel Gabriel. Bastion de Santo Domingo is so named because of its close proximity to the Dominican compound. The bastion was demolished in the 20th century.

Puertas. Piercing the fortification wall and allowing controlled access in and out of the walled city were puertas or gates. Some gates had drawbridges, which in the 19th century were raised at 11 in the evening, when a curfew was imposed. The principal gates were Real and Parian. Real (royal) was a ceremonial gate used by the governor-general and the archbishop of Manila. In 1780, it was relocated where it presently stands, along Muralla St. The gate is protected by the Revellin de la Puerta Real and a curved stone bridge. The Parian gate faced Manila’s Chinese quarters.

Near Parian and along the north curtain wall is Puerta de Isabel II, named in honor of Queen Isabel II. It was the last gate to be built in 1861. It replaced Magallanes, a small gate that opened to the Pasig River bank and the monument to Ferdinand Magellan, along the southern bank of the Pasig River. Santo Domingo was built near the Dominican compound. The gate and the bastion named Santo Domingo were demolished in 1904 to open the city to commerce along the Pasig. Almacenes, located between the Intendencia and Fort Santiago, was likewise demolished in 1904, together with a length of curtain wall from San Juan de Letrán to Fort Santiago.

On the seaward and western side are Postigo or postern gate, used as an emergency exit and Santa Lucia, near the San Agustin cloister. Badly damaged during World War II, it was rebuilt following original plans. The drawbridge was restored and part of the moat passing under the bridge was rebuilt.

As in all bastioned forts, straight walls called cortina or curtain wall, connected the bastions. The cortina did not have specific names unlike the bastions.

Within the walls were military and civic buildings, hospitals, schools, churches, chapels and convents, and private residences.

Military Buildings. Maestranza was a weapons arsenal outside Fort Santiago. Beside it was a foundry, Herrerias. Nothing remains of either structure. There is no clear data how the buildings looked. They were probably functional boxy structures, with little ornamentation.

The barracks on the fort’s western flank, undamaged during World War II, was restored for the centennial of Rizal’s birth in 1961 and redesigned in 1996, the centennial of the Philippine Revolution and Rizal’s execution. Since 1961, the barracks has been called Rizal Shrine to commemorate and honor the national hero. It houses memorabilia, copies of Rizal’s writing, and award-winning paintings depicting moments Rizal’s life. The paintings were made in 1961 for the national hero’s birth centennial. A room has been converted to a life-sized diorama depicting Rizal’s incarceration in Fort Santiago, prior to his execution. Rizal, contrary to common belief, was not incarcerated in this building but in the one opposite it beside the Pasig River. This is now in ruins and has been reused as an open theater, Rajah Sulayman Theater.

Fundicion or foundry, beside Bastion de San Diego, was built on a site said to have been the workshop of Panday Pira. Nothing remains of the structure.

Cuarteles de España was built on the site of the ruined 17th-century San Ignacio. Nothing remains of the structure. The site is presently occupied by the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. The only visual evidence left of the Cuarteles is an 1852 proposal of Manuel Herbella, where a floor plan in red ink is superimposed over the floor plan of the San Ignacio and the adjoining cloister, drawn in black. There are no remains of the Cuarteles de España.

Cuartel de Santa Lucia, located near the Santa Lucia gate, was built in 1781 as the barracks for the Artelleria de la Montaña, following the plans of Tomas Sanz. In 1901, the Philippine Constabulary (PC) occupied the building, and on 17 Feb 1905 the Philippine Officers School was opened at the site. In 1908, the school was moved to Baguio, where it was renamed Philippine Military Academy (PMA). Damaged during World War II, its walls were reconstructed by the PC, which owned the property, but the interior was not rebuilt. What has remained after the restoration is a facade in the neoclassical style, with the central section and portal slightly higher than the rest because of the addition of a pediment.

Hospital Militar was located near the Monasterio de Santa Clara, facing the Ayuntamiento. The Capilla Militar, dedicated to the Incarnation of Jesus, was the military chapel. It faced Plaza Militar, outside Fort Santiago. No remains of these structures stand.

Civic Buildings. The first residence of the governor-generals, Palacio del Gobernador, was built near Fort Santiago. During the governorship of Fausto Cruzat y Gongora (1690-1701), a building following an atrial plan was built at the present site of the Palacio. The southern side of the Palacio was used as a palace, and the north was used by the Audiencia. In 1850, the palace was given a neoclassical facade. The building was characterized by its arched windows and entrances, three arched entrances all told, and its rusticated stone work at the first floor. The upper floor was ornamented by engaged columns. The building suffered damage during the earthquake of 3 Jun 1863. After laying new foundations, plans to restore the Palacio were abandoned when another earthquake struck in 1880. It was decided to transfer the palace to the Malacañan. The building remained in ruins until it was rebuilt by Imelda Marcos and used as the office of the Ministry of Human Settlements. The reconstruction had been controversial from the very start. Preserving the remaining walls of the two-story palacio, the reconstruction added twelve more stories, almost exceeding the height of the Manila Cathedral’s bell tower. Laws covering post-World War II development in Intramuros stipulated nothing could be built taller than the Cathedral’s bell tower, as had been the law during the Spanish colonial era.

Ayuntamiento, also known as cabildo and casas consistoriales, was the city hall of the City of Manila where the cabildo or city council met. An early building of cut stone was built before 1607, and rebuilt in 1684, probably because it was damaged by an earthquake. A new building was constructed from 1735 to 1738; it survived to the 18th century. A new neoclassical building was designed by Eduardo Navarro. Construction began in 1879 and was completed about 1885. In the 20th century, it was the site of the Philippine Assembly of 1907. Its most celebrated room was the Marble Hall, noted for its harlequin floor of white and black marble. The building was ruined in 1945 and remained in ruins for more than seven decades. It was reconstructed in 2011 by the Bureau of Treasury and reused as its main office. The main section, including the celebrated Marble Hall has been reconstructed, but the wings flanking the main section have interiors that, while respecting the historic structure, have been made functional as a modern office. In the reconstruction, the lines of the original 19th-century plan were followed, preserving the arched doorway, quadrilateral windows, rustication on the first floor, while the balconies of the second were repaired and reconstructed.

The Audiencia was the supreme court of Spanish colonial Philippines. It shared the same building as the Palacio until 1788, when a site was purchased and built for it across Aduana St. The Audiencia building was connected to the Palacio by a bridge over Aduana. The Audiencia had its own chapel and a jail. The building was damaged by the earthquake of 1863 and never rebuilt. Its site is presently occupied by a fire station. Very little evidence exists to describe the Audiencia building.

The Aduana or Customs house, also known as Intendencia, replaced the Alcaiceria de San Fernando which was built in 1752. It was located on the northern bank of the Pasig River. The Aduana followed the neoclassical design of Tomas Cortes. Plans for the building were submitted in 1822 and construction began the following year. It was completed in 1829. The building also housed the city corporation or Intendencia. It was damaged during World War II and remains as a ruin. There were plans to restore the building to house the Spanish collection of the National Archives, officially known as Records Management and Archival Office (RMAO). The building is a two-story structure built around anatrium. The facade is divided into five sections. The central portion has three arched portals corresponding to three bays, above the bays are grilled balconies accessed through French windows. On either side of the central portion are five bays. The pair nearest the center is projected slightly forward over the remaining four. These bays have quadrilateral windows and oculi on the first floor and the arched windows on the second floor. The arched windows were apparently a renovation. Antique photographs show that the oculi, rather than arched windows, pierced this section of the wall. The corner bays are about the same dimension as the central section; the first floor has a quadrilateral window and the second floor a balcony and French windows, topped by an ornamental triangular pediment. The central and corner sections have pilasters defining the vertical sweep of the building. The pilasters have garlanded Ionic capitals.

Churches, Convents, and Monasteries. Intramuros was the city of churches and convents. It was the seat of archdiocese of Manila, the Metropolitan or main archdiocese under which all other dioceses fell. In it were the motherhouses of the religious orders, the contemplative nuns, sisters, and beatas.

The Catedral Mayor de Manila was dedicated to the Inmaculada Concepcion. It was rebuilt at least eight times, the last after World War II, between 1954 and 1958. The 1958 reconstruction incorporated parts of the neo-Romanesque cathedral built after the earthquakes of 1863 and 1872.

Sagrario, built beside the cathedral as a chapel of the cathedral canons, was not rebuilt after it was damaged by the earthquake of 1880.

San Agustin, the oldest church in the Philippines, was begun in 1587 and completed in 1607. The church and the adjoining monastery cloister survived World War II. The second and third cloisters were damaged. Presently, the surviving cloister has a museum of religious art. The area of the second cloister has been partially rebuilt. An Augustinian novitiate and seminary were built on the site of the third cloister. The new building is in the colonial style although it is not a reconstruction of the third cloister.

San Agustin church, as it is popularly known, was dedicated to San Pablo. It consisted of a single nave, flanked by collateral chapels that serve as internal buttresses to the structure. The chapels terminate just outside the sanctuary and the shallow dome, in front of the sanctuary, to form a cruciform plan. The altars in the church range in style from the baroque to the neoclassical. Outstanding is the trompe l’oiel painting of the church and the grille work that leads from the transept to the cloister. Also noteworthy is the church’s stone vault, the only such vault that has survived almost intact from the colonial era. The church facade is plain, two stories with a triangular pediment and flanked by bell towers. The tower on the gospel side was damaged by the earthquake of 1872, taken down, and never rebuilt.

San Francisco was the popular name of the Franciscan church in Intramuros. Thirteen Franciscans arrived in Manila in 1578, the second religious order to arrive in the Philippines. By 1602, they had built a church of stone dedicated to Our Lady of the Angels. Other churches were built before that. The church, begun in 1739, survived in substance to the 20th century, but was destroyed during World War II, with only its facade remaining. The facade was torn down after the war during the clean-up of Intramuros. It was in the baroque style. The church was tall and narrow, rising to three stories, and capped by a truncated triangular pediment. Over the pediment, the bell tower was built in a style reminiscent of the espadaña belfry. The facade was divided into five sections, where the corner vertical sections projected beyond the line of the facade forming buttresses . The remaining three sections were defined by engaged Corinthian columns, single at the side and double at the central section for the church’s main entrance. The facade was divided horizontally by pairs of bands and the walls decorated with niches and windows. Blind hexagonal windows decorated the pediment and the third story of the bays flanking the central section. The second story, corresponding to the choir loft, had arched windows; Roman at the side and trefoil Mudejar arches for the center.

Venerable Tercera Orden (VOT) church was built perpendicular to San Francisco for members of the lay branch of the Franciscan order or Third Order (tertiaries). The church was dedicated to the Inmaculada Conception and constructed from 1723 to 1734. During World War II, the church suffered the same fate as the San Francisco. It bore striking similarities with the San Francisco, being three stories and divided into five bays. But the differences are obvious at the uppermost story, where the pediment is not truncated but rather triangular and integrated into flanking straight parapets. Over the bays flanking the central entrance are bell towers crowned with spire-like roof reminiscent of neo-Gothic . After World War II, the VOT church was not rebuilt, rather the tertiaries of Intramuros merged with the tertiaries of Sampaloc, where a postwar VOT church was built beside the Church of Our Lady of Loreto.

Recoletos was the church built by a reformed branch of the Augustinian order that arrived in Manila in 1606. The church was built in the lot presently occupied by The Manila Bulletin. The church that survived to the 20th century, like the San Francisco, rose to three stories. The tall third and uppermost story, which is integrated into the triangular pediment, gave the church extra height equivalent to a four-story building. Blind octagonal oculi decorate the pediment, while niches and windows decorate the three vertical sections of the facade. The bell tower to the left of the facade rested on a tall plinth. Consisting of four stories of diminishing dimensions, it was capped by a bell-shaped stone roof.

It was the church interior, however, that distinguished the church.The main altar was in the baroque style. Divided into niches and stories, the gilded retablo alternated images and painted canvases. In this church, the famous Recollect organ builder, Fr Diego Cera, who built the Las Piñas bamboo organ, constructed his masterpiece. He built a massive pipe organ, outfitting the nave with pipes, some ingenuously hidden along the sides of the nave so that when sounded, the walls themselves seemed to sing.

The Jesuits built two churches called San Ignacio, in honor of their founder Ignatius of Loyola, on two different sites. The first was completed 1632, destroyed by the 1852 earthquake; and the second was completed 1889, destroyed in 1945. The first San Ignacio was baroque, the second was neoclassical. The Italian Jesuit priest-architect, Gianantonio Campioni, designed the first San Ignacio. The construction of the church began in 1626 and was completed in 1632. This was actually the third church built by the Jesuits at the site presently occupied by the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. A first church of wood with a tile roof was built in 1587, with donations from the oidor (judge) Don Gabriel de Ribera. A second church of stone, dedicated to Santa Ana, the mother of the Virgin Mary, was built between 1590-96, following plans drawn up by the Jesuit Antonio Sedeño. The church was modeled upon Il Gesú, the Jesuits’s mother church in Rome. The church was damaged by the earthquake of 1600. The third church as it came from Campioni may have been more Italianate baroque rather than Spanish. In the 18th century the church was solemnly consecrated after being renovated by the imposition of bas-relief foliage in the voids of the facade making it appear more Plateresque than Italianate. The decorations were not received favorably by all. The church interior was painted by the Jesuit brother Manuel Rodriguez, assisted by Tagalog apprentices, in 1700.

The Jesuits were expelled from the Philippines in 1768 and their properties confiscated and placed on public auction. Abandoned from 1768 to 1784, the church deteriorated. In 1771, the archbishop of Manila requested authorization to use the Colegio de Manila, adjacent to the church for the Seminario de San Carlos, but approval was not given immediately. The seminary took possession of the college and church in 1784. The church was damaged beyond repair by the earthquake of 6 Sep 1852.

The second San Ignacio was built along Arzobispo St, beside the archbishop’s palace. It was designed by Felix Roxas Sr. The wooden interior and statuary were designed and executed by Isabelo Tampinco and his atelier from 1882 onward. The altars and pulpit by Agustin Saez, who was director of the art academy in Manila and art teacher at the Ateneo Municipal. This church was completed in 1889. The second San Ignacio was in the neoclassical idiom, although its interior with an arcade and elevated galleries running the length of the nave was more Renaissance in style. So was the church’s artesonado or coffered ceiling. The facade was built of bricks and piedra de Visayas (coral or limestone), with white Cararra marble used for the engaged pillars, portals, and windows. The interior was covered with dark hardwood from the forests of Surigao. Wood relieves of Jesuit saints decorated the interior. The church survived the fire that ravaged the Ateneo in 1932. When the Ateneo moved to Ermita, the church became a parish. The church was ruined during the liberation of Manila in 1945. The property was acquired by the city of Manila and rented out to different companies. At one time it was the E.J. Neil Warehouse. The ruined walls of San Ignacio still stood after World War II.

After completing the archaeological survey of the site of the church and the adjoining lot, where the Casa Mision or the Jesuit headquarters once stood, the Intramuros Administration (IA) began working on the reconstruction of the church, which would be reused as the IA’s museum of ecclesiastical art. The reconstruction is ongoing.

Beside San Ignacio stood the Casa Mision, the residence of the Jesuits in Intramuros, which housed both the faculty of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila and the Jesuit superiors of the Philippine Mission. The Casa Mision was built like a typical 19th century bahay na bato (stone house) with a lower story of stone and an upper story of wood. The city government authorized the construction of a covered bridge above Anda Street linking the Casa Mision with the Ateneo Municipal.

The Capuchino was built by a branch of the Franciscan order called the Capuchins, who are so named because of the color of their habits. All its members sported full beards, which distinguished them further from the Franciscans. The Capuchins introduced devotion to Our Lady of Lourdes. They built the church along Calle Real del Palacio, which was completed in 1894. It was the last of the Spanish colonial churches to be built. The design was modern in orientation, a simplified version of Romanesque. Planned as a cruciform, with a dome at the transept crossing, the church was characterized by a repetitive and harmonious use of the Roman arch. Its facade was flanked by bell towers, quadrilateral in design and crowned by domes and lanterns. The Roman arches were used in the portals and the windows. The church had three arched portals corresponding to the nave and the lateral aisles. Inside, the space was defined by a colonnade , above which were galleries. The faux vault was a semicircular arch. The sanctuary had a neoclassical altar composed of three arch niches. The church was damaged in 1945.

The church site is now occupied by El Amanecer, which houses Silahis Arts & Artifacts, and the Ilustrado Restaurant. After World War II, the Capuchins transferred their central house to Quezon City, in a lot along Retiro St, where they built a church in honor of Our Lady of Lourdes. Like the Lourdes of Intramuros, the church in Quezon City was Manila’s favorite for fashionable weddings.

Santo Domingo was built beside the University of Santo Tomas on the northeastern flank of Intramuros, near the Pasig. Four other churches had been built on the site before the fifth, and last of the Santo Domingos was constructed. It was in the neo-Gothic style, designed by Felix Roxas Sr, with construction supervised by Fr Sixto, OP and Fr Ristoro, OP. It was completed in 1865. The church was damaged by Japanese bombardment on 21 Dec 1941, the first church to be destroyed during World War II. Although built to honor Santo Domingo de Guzman, founder of the Dominican order, the church was better known for the Feast of La Naval, celebrated annually on 7 Oct. This feast in honor of Our Lady of the Rosary commemorates the victory of the Spanish against the Dutch, who tried to invade Manila.

The Roxas-designed church replaced an earlier church, the fourth on the spot, which had just inaugurated a new facade on 15 Jun 1862. It was demolished by the devastating earthquake of 1863. The facade was said to have been patterned after Christopher Wren’s plans for St Paul’s in London, i.e. it was in the neoclassical idiom.

Roxas opted for another Revivalist style, the neo-Gothic. But because neo-Gothic was characterized by height, Roxas designed the fifth Santo Domingo such that the upper story was made of wood and metal, resting on a lower story of stone, as a precaution against earthquakes. The neo-Gothic idiom adapted throughout the church was evident in both the exterior and interior—lancet windows, tracery, even the altars and the furniture were embellished with neo-Gothic motifs.

Although the church was destroyed in 1941, some of its appurtenances, especially the ivory image of the Santo Rosario, sculpted in 1595, were saved because they had been kept in the church’s vault. The site of Santo Domingo is presently occupied by Far East Bank, Tuason-Gonzales Bldg, Beneficial Life, Letrán’s gym, and a parking lot. After World War II, the Dominicans built a new Santo Domingo, designed by Jose Maria Zaragoza in the Spanish Moderne style, along Quezon Blvd in Quezon City.

Real Monasterio de Santa Clara was the monastery of the Clarisas, the female branch of the Franciscan order that traces its origin to Santa Clara de Asis. The royal monastery in Manila was founded by Sor Geronima Asuncíon, a relative of the Spanish monarch, in 1621. Arriving in April that year, in the same ship taken by Bp Juan de Renteria who was appointed to Nueva Segovia, were 24 Franciscan nuns. After staying for a while in the house owned by Doña Ana de Vera in Sampaloc, they moved to the Franciscan convent in the same village until 31 Oct, when they took possession of two houses in Intramuros owned by De Vera and Maestre de Campo Pedro Chaves. The following year, a church dedicated to the Immaculate Conception was built beside the residence. Fr Diego de la Torre, who had worked as a master builder at the Escorial, supervised its construction. The nuns remained in the convent until 1658, when an earthquake forced them to live in a private house in the walled city until such time as they were able to raise a new convent and church.

Following their rules of seclusion, the nuns built a 30-foot windowless wall that cut them from the city. Located at the northeastern quadrant of the city, between Plaza Militar and the city walls, the nuns enjoyed seclusion and privacy. Architecturally the monastery compound was simple and undistinguished, in keeping with the austerity of the Poor Clares.

Damaged during World War II, the Intramuros monastery was not rebuilt. The Monasterio de Santa Clara transferred to Katipunan Ave in Quezon City, on a site overlooking the Marikina Valley.

Beaterio de la Compañia was founded by Mother Ignacia del Espiritu Santo, a mestiza Chinese from Binondo. The turn of the 19th century beaterio was located along Santa Lucia, near the Colegio de San Ignacio. The beatas went to the Jesuits for spiritual direction and church services. The beaterio was damaged during World War II and the site became a warehouse. The beaterio was restored by the Department of Tourism and became a history museum featuring life-size dioramas. The Spanish colonial beaterio was a long building, sparsely ornamented. Its only distinctive feature was the chapel at the north end of the building, which had a pitched roof. Otherwise the building would have been a plain box.

Beaterio de Santa Catalina was founded by the Dominican tertiaries in 1633. Its building was not rebuilt. The Dominican tertiaries transferred to Quezon City, where Sienna College was established.

Educational Institutions. Universidad de Santo Tomas is the oldest continually existing university in the Philippines. It was established by the Dominicans in 1611, and was initially funded by a bequest from Abp Miguel de Benavides, OP, who left his library and 1,000 pesos to the Dominicans in his will. It received the name Colegio de Santo Tomas in 1617 and, in 1619, occupied its own building. In 1623, Philip IV authorized the college to teach grammar, arts, and theology. A papal brief authorized it to confer degrees. In 1680, it was given royal protection and came to be known as a Royal university, hence the honorific title the university bears today “Real y pontificia universidád” (Royal and pontifical university). After the expulsion of the Jesuits from the Philippines in 1768, the Dominicans acquired the abandoned buildings of the Jesuits where they opened the university’s college of medicine and pharmacy. They also took charge of the diocesan seminary, housed in what was formerly the Colegio de San Jose. Damaged during World War II, the university reopened at its Sampaloc campus, established in 1940, a year before the war’s Pacific campaign.

Fernandez de Roxas’s map of 1727 depicts Santo Tomas as a simple atrial-type structure near the convent of Santo Domingo. The structure enclosed a garden and was distinguished by a tall tower on its northern flank. From 1625 to 1940, the famous printing press of Santo Tomas was located in the wing nearest the Pasig. The press had moved from the Parian to different provinces, and then to the Hospital de San Gabriel from 1621 to 1625. The 19th century Santo Tomas building was in the style of a bahay na bato, where the upper story overhung the lower story. The facade, built in the 18th century, was remodeled to make it appear more monumental sometime in the 20th century, a few years before the building’s destruction in 1945. Except for the main portal, the windows and apertures of the building were quadrilateral. The main entrance, made of adobe, had a semicircular portal flanked by niches with trefoil arches. Pilasters separated the portal from the niches. The central portal led straight to another arch portal, which led to the atrium around which other wings of the university were built.

Ateneo Municipal de Manila was turned over to Jesuit administration by the city of Manila in 1859. In Dec 1859, the Jesuits began instruction in a modest building along Arzobispo St, near the archbishop’s residence. Founded and supported by the city, the school was allowed to bear Manila’s coat of arms. The institution began as a boarding school but started accepting day boarders. This school was later expanded with the addition of a preparatory college that prepared students for studies in the university, offering such courses as pre-law, surveying, and mechanics.

The school was built around an atrium on a lot bounded by Arzobispo, Santa Lucia, and Anda. The school building was two stories and resembled a bahay na bato, with a lower story of stone and an upper one of wood. At the turn of the 19th century, a third floor was added to the school buildings. In the early 20th century, an elaborate entrance was designed and executed by Isabelo Tampinco. After a fire in 1932 that ravaged the southwestern quadrant of Intramuros, and the Ateneo with it, the student boarders moved to a building in Ermita which was built for the Escuela Normal de San Francisco Xavier, a school for teachers which closed in 1902. During World War II, the Ateneo moved its quarters to different parts of the city while trying to maintain a semblance of normality. By the end of the war, the buildings on Ermita, along the road now named after the Jesuit founder of the Manila Observatory, Fr Federico Faura, were in ruins. In 1951, the Jesuits transferred the Ateneo to Loyola Heights in Quezon City, where it has remained. In 1959, Ateneo became a university.

The Colegio de Manila (Colegio de San Ignacio) was established by the Jesuits in 1595 for the children of the Spanish community in Manila. The school opened its door to students in 1596. The college building, described as sumptuous and beautiful was damaged by the earthquake of 1645. The building was apparently repaired a number of times, following, for instance, another earthquake in 1658. With the expulsion of the Jesuits in 1768, the college was dissolved and its buildings sequestered by the government. The archbishop of Manila requested to use the building and the adjacent church for the Seminario de San Carlos in 1771. In 1784, the seminary finally occupied the buildings. In the 19th century, the college and church site were taken over by the military and became the Cuarteles de España. Whatever remained of the ancient building was razed in 1900, when the American 31st Infantry took over from the Spanish. The church site became a basketball court for soldiers.

The college building was built around an atrium and rose to three stories in some parts. In the college was the Imprenta de la Compañia, responsible for publishing the first Tagalog pasyon in 1703, the 1734 map of Pedro Murillo Velarde, and the dictionaries of Mateo Sanchez and Juan de Noceda and Pedro de San Lucar. Bro Georg Kamel, noted for his botanical studies, kept a garden of Philippine flora and opened a pharmacy there. The site is presently occupied by the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila.

Colegio de San Juan de Letran, a school run by the Dominicans, traces its origins to two institutions—Colegio de Niños Huerfanos, founded by Capitán Juan Rodrigo Jeronimo Guerrero in 1620 as a school for orphaned boys, chiefly children of military personnel; and Colegio de Huerfanos de San José y San Pablo founded by Bro Diego de Sta Maria, OP. Guerrero’s school began in a modest house in front of the Hospital de San Juan de Dios and near the Parian gate. Guerrero not only educated the boys but also fed and clothed them. The number of students grew steadily, and Guerrero, who had become a Dominican brother, appealed for public support. King Philip IV placed the school under Royal protection in 1623. Guerrero’s school was merged with the Dominicans’s foundation in 1640. The Dominicans built a stone building for 200 students for the merged schools near their church. But in 1645 an earthquake destroyed the building so the students were temporarily moved to the Parian until 1668 when a new school building was opened in its present site in Intramuros. (Interestingly, the Muñoz map of 1671 depicts Letrán as still occupying a lot in Parian.)

A fourth structure was built at the corner of the Baluarte de San Gabriel in 1699. Letrán has since occupied this site.In 1690, the school was elevated to an ecclesiastical college. In 1865, it was classified as a colegio de primera clase en Filipinas. The turn-of-the-century school building was in the style of the bahay na bato but with the influence of the Victorian gingerbread house style, evident in its delicate wooden tracery and pierced soffit ceiling. That building was apparently replaced by a three-story structure, which was completed in 1937, a few years before the outbreak of war. The school buildings were damaged twice during World War II. First, in 1941 during the initial bombing of Manila, and second in 1945, during the liberation of the city.

Rebuilt and renovated after the war, the school occupied the same lot it owned since the late 17th century. The 20th century building alluded to Spanish colonial style in ornamentation but is basically a modern building. When the Colegio de Santa Catalina transferred to Quezon City, Letran acquired its site and blocked off the street that separated Letrán from Santa Catalina, forming one large lot. A street perpendicular to the school site is named San Juan de Letrán.

Colegio de San Jose was founded in 1586 by a royal decree for candidates to the priesthood and for Spanish boys and mestizos. In 1595, Gov-Gen Gomez Perez de Dasmariñas set aside 1,000 pesos for 10 scholars, and in 1596, Esteban de Figueroa, encomendero of Oton, bequeathed his fortune toward the foundation of the school. The Jesuits inaugurated the college in 1601; but by 1605 its buildings were recorded as needing repair.In 1610, the college was reorganized as an endowed school (funds from Figueroa’s estate) and obras pias. In 1641, Gov-Gen Hurtado de Corcuera ordered the street separating San José and the Colegio de Manila closed, creating one large compound for the Jesuit institutions. The earthquakes of 1645 and 1648 damaged the college building. The building was apparently being repaired or renovated when the Jesuits were expelled in 1768. The building was then acquired by the archbishop of Manila for the seminarians of the archdiocese. In 1870, a royal decree classified San José’s assets as government property and the college was secularized. In 1875, the secularization decree was repealed, and San José became a college of medicine under the king and the governor. Day-to-day administration was turned over to the Dominicans.

San José was planned as a two-story E-shaped building enclosing two gardens. The longest wing was parallel to Muralla, and the westernmost wing apparently housed a stable. The college building was destroyed during World War II. The site is presently occupied by the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. Near the college, the Jesuits opened a school for boys and girls but its precise location is uncertain.

Beaterio y Colegio de Santa Catalina has a long history. In 1633, female Dominican tertiaries, under Mother Francisca del Espiritu Santo and companions requested permission to establish a beaterio and a college. The request was met with opposition from the Franciscan tertiaries who claimed that there were already too many beaterios. But Carlos II authorized the foundation, which was known as the Dominican sisters of the tertiary order.In 1696, a house was opened behind Letrán, at the corner of Beaterio and Cerrada (now San Juan de Letrán). In 1706, a college for girls was established and in 1716 was placed under royal patronage. By the mid-19th century, it was a college of note and was converted to the Escuela Normal de Maestras. In 1863, it was authorized to offer teacher-training, and starting in 1881 conferred the academic degree of maestra normal.

The college buildings in the style of an oversized bahay na bato were damaged in the earthquake of 1863 and 1880, but by 1883 had been rebuilt. In 1894, the building was expanded and, in 1939, another story and a new facade were added. Damaged in World War II by Japanese bombs, the buildings were no longer usable, so the tertiaries moved the college to Legarda St, while the tertiaries’s convent was moved to Sampaloc. The college building was not rebuilt after the war and San Juan de Letrán acquired the school site. After the war, the beatas were reorganized as the Congregation of St Catherine of Siena. In 1962, the school transferred to Quezon City and is now known as Siena College (shortened from Santa Catalina de Siena).

Colegio de Santa Isabel was established in 1594 by the Hermandad de la Santa Misericordia with the sole purpose of aiding the Hospital de San Juan de Dios. Later, the brotherhood took on the burden of being the patron of a school founded in 1632 for the daughters of military personnel who died leaving no inheritance for their children. The college was initially housed in a private residence until a lot was found near San Agustin, along Real del Palacio corner of Recogida. In 1733, the college received Royal protection. In 1800 the college boasted of capacious and sumptuous buildings. It was a two-story structure which was built longitudinally. It was very similar to a bahay na bato. Damaged by the 1863 earthquake, the school was rebuilt. The following year administration transferred to the Daughters of Charity and, in 1866, the Colegio de Santa Potenciana was merged with it. In 1882, the offices of Monte de Piedad were opened in the college building. Because of the numerous donations and endowments, the college was perhaps the most important institution for women. Under the Daughters of Charity, the school was modernized, achieving a level similar to that in Spain.

In 1945, the college buildings were completely destroyed. The sisters transferred the school to a new site along Taft Ave where it continues in its task of education. The ancient college had a miraculous crucifix called Cristo del Tesoro, because it belonged to the Royal treasury. The crucifix is in the chapel of the modern school edifice. The site of Santa Isabel in Intramuros is now occupied by the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines (CBCP).

Real Colegio de Santa Potenciana, the oldest school for young girls, was established in 1589 by Philip II, upon the urging of Manila bishop Domingo de Salazar, OP and the Franciscans.In 1592, the school drew up its charter. The same year, Capitán Luis de Vivanco donated the original site for the college, where a wooden house was built as dwelling and school for orphaned girls. The college had apparently improved its buildings subsequently because it was reported that in 1645 an earthquake had destroyed the college, now apparently made of stone. By the 17th century, the school had transferred to the corner of Cabildo and Santa Potenciana, according to the Muñoz map of 1671. By the end of the 18th century, a new structure had to be constructed, as the school building was in ruins because, according to Zuñiga, it was poorly built in the first place. By the 19th century, Santa Potenciana had transferred its site to the corner of Real del Palacio and Santa Potenciana. The exact year is uncertain, although a map of Manila published in Buzeta, 1851, indicates the school still occupied its old site at this time. On the new site, a new structure may have been built by the first half of the 19th century because after the 1863 earthquake had destroyed the Palacio, government offices were moved to this building in 1866. By this time enrollment in the school had considerably dropped and the handful of student boarders were made to transfer to the Colegio de Santa Isabel. Merging the two institutions of learning resulted in the dissolution of the Colegio de Santa Potenciana.

Veterans Bank and the Red Cross building presently occupy the old site of Santa Potenciana and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts building.

Colegio de Santa Rosa, also known as Colegio de Madre Paula, was initially known as Beaterio y Casa de Enseñanza. Colegio de Santa Rosa was established for the education of orphaned girls by Madre Paula de Santisima Trinidad in 1750. The college occupied a lot in front of the UST. In 1739, this lot was occupied by a small residence, which had to be demolished to make way for the school building. Beside the school, a beaterio was built. In 1774, the school and beaterio were placed under royal patronage. Both institutions were later turned to the care of the Dominican friars, but passed to the Royal Audiencia in 1784, and then to a junta of alumnae and matrons of the city until 1886, when administration was transferred to the Daughters of Charity (Paules sisters), who renamed the school Colegio de Santa Rosa.

Although damaged in 1863 by an earthquake and by another one in 1880, a new and bigger structure was built in place of the ruins. By the turn of the century, the college was one of the more important institutions of learning for women .The building was destroyed by the initial bombing of Manila in 1941, forcing the sisters to transfer the school to Santa Mesa. In 1949, the school returned to Intramuros, but under new administrators—the sisters of the Siervas de San Jose. In 1981, the sisters transferred administration to the Augustinian Recollect sisters who run the school today. Although the postwar school buildings followed the modern style, the buildings have recently undergone a facelift and the turn-of-the-century facade of Santa Rosa has been recreated in concrete rather than in wood, which was used in the original. This was characterized by a chamfered corner, where the building facade was located. This was a tall and narrow structure crowned by a semicircular pediment.

Hospitals. San Juan de Dios, the first hospital in Intramuros, was established by Fr Juan Clemente, OFM, in 1578. A modest structure of nipa and bamboo consisting of two wards was built facing the Franciscan porteria or porter’s lodge of the Franciscan convento. In 1596, it was placed under the patronage of the Misericordia. Administration was given to the brothers of San Juan de Dios in 1656. Nothing remains of the hospital, but plans and turn-of-the-19th-century photographs show the hospital to be a plain building of two stories, functional and bereft of much ornamentation. An 18th-century plan of the San Juan de Dios church shows it to be baroque in style. It was cruciform with the main altar with multiple niches and side altars at the transept ends. Its interior had a raised gallery running the length of the nave, beneath that were smaller altars. The facade was flanked by bell towers capped by a pointed roof. The facade was divided into vertical and horizontal sections with niches for statues, reminiscent of a retablo.

Monuments. Monuments to honor important persons were part of the urban plan of Intramuros. The Monumento de Magallanes, built to honor Ferdinand Magellan, originally stood in front of Puerta Isabel II, but was moved behind the Intendencia building after part of the wall was demolished in 1904. The monument, which was an obelisk crowned with an armillary sphere and adorned by ships prows at the pedestal, was completely damaged by war and collapsed into the Pasig River.

Monument to Isabel II, formerly at Plaza Arroceros, was transferred in front of Malate church, but was damaged by a typhoon. The restored bronze statue was placed in front of Puerta Isabel II in 1971.

Monument to Carlos IV was erected in 1824, to honor the king for sending cholera vaccine to the Philippines. The bronze statue was cast in the Herrerias or royal foundry at Intramuros, and placed on a pedestal in the Plaza Mayor of Manila, an open space surrounded by the Manila Cathedral, the Palacio del Gobernador, the Real Audiencia, and the Ayuntamiento. In 1886, a fountain at the base of the statue was added.

Monument to Abp Benavides was originally in Plaza Santo Tomas, facing the university. The bronze statue of Benavides is dressed as a Dominican, but with a pectoral cross and skull cap, which are symbols of a bishop. It was cast in Paris by Tony Noel in 1889. It was erected on a marble pedestal and unveiled on 2 Jul 1891. The statue was blown off its base when the pedestal was hit by artillery in 1945. On 12 Nov 1946, the statue was transferred to and re-erected in the Sampaloc campus of the university, together with the principal entrance of the university.

Monument to Legazpi and Urdaneta was cast at the turn of the century in Spain, but the monument was not completed until 1904. It visually summarizes the close ties between Church and State. While Miguel Lopez de Legazpi holds a flag, Fr Andres Urdaneta, OSA raises a cross.

Although located outside Intramuros in a rotunda along Bonifacio Drive, the Monument to Simon de Anda is considered as within the boundaries of Intramuros as a historical district. The monument honors Anda who, from a base in Bulacan, continued the resistance against the British, so much so that the British were confined to occupying Manila and little else beyond. Anda served as governor for a government in exile from 1762 to 1764. At the end of the British occupation, Anda became governor-general (1770-76). The monument is an obelisk resting on tall plinth. The obelisk is topped by a mace.

Residences. Residences, owned by private individuals, clustered in and near Barrio San Luis, located east of San Agustin monastery. Hardly any of the pre-World War II residences, many in the style of the bahay na bato, survived the bombardment of Intramuros in Feb 1945 at the end of the war. Fronting San Agustin church and convento, Casa Manila, a house museum, as well as the adjacent period houses were erected using old plans. They attempt to evoke the memory of the Spanish colonial era residences in Intramuros.  Written by René B. Javellana

article.value: The name Intramuros comes from the Latin words “intra,” meaning “within” and “muros,” meaning “walls.” Intramuros is located on the southern bank of the Pasig River, near the river’s mouth. Laid out as an irregular pentagon with an area of 0.67 sq km, Intramuros is enclosed by a 3.7-km-long wall. It is also known as Ciudad Murada or the Walled City.

Intramuros was established in 1571. This was the center of Spanish colonial government, the civil, ecclesiastical, educational, economic, and cultural center of the Philippines for more than three centuries. It was also a residential area for Spanish colonists. Other ethnic groups, like the Chinese and the Tagalog, lived outside the walled city.

article.value: The Intramuros Heritage Area is comprised of two parts: a military area, Fort Santiago, and a civilian area, the Spanish ciudad or city of Manila. Fort Santiago occupies the northwestern apex of the walled city, while the rest comprises the ciudad.

Intramuros was laid out as a grid of streets with open and green spaces called plazas and spaces for a variety of buildings, following the principles of Renaissance urban planning as codified in the 1573 Laws of the Indies.

Streets. The principal streets, which defined the city plan, runs northwest to southeast. These streets are Calle Real del Palacio and Calle (Real del) Parian, which set the grid layout of the city. Renaissance town planners drew inspiration from the classical era: Calle Real del Palacio was analogous to classical Rome’s cardo and Calle Parian was analogous to the decumanus. Calle Real, now Gen Luna, was originally named for the governor general’s palace, Palacio del Gobernador, and later renamed to honor Gen Antonio Luna, brother of the painter Juan Luna and an officer of the revolutionary army against Spain.

Calle (Real del) Parian was initially called Parian because it led to the Parian gate and ravelin. The street runs perpendicular to Real del Palacio and crosses it, three blocks south of the Manila Cathedral and in front of San Agustin Monastery. Called Real after 1780, when Puerta Real at the end of Calle Real was closed as a precaution against a siege, Real del Parian became the ceremonial street through which the carriages of the governor-general and the archbishop of Manila passed. Calle Parian led to the business district and Chinese enclave outside Intramuros located north and east, at the areas presently occupied by the Central Post Office, the Metropolitan Theater, the LRT Central Station, and the Arroceros Forest Park.

Within the walls, a perimeter road follows the line of the walls. Its name varies depending on where it runs. It is called Muralla at its northeastern section. At the southwestern section it is called Fundición (foundry) because it passes a military foundry at the Baluarte de San Diego, as depicted in 18th century maps. The length of the perimeter road that runs parallel to the seaside flank of the city walls, passing by Santa Lucia gate, became known as Santa Lucia.

These secondary roads run on the city’s northwest-southeast axis: Arzobispo was named for the archbishop’s palace, which was located along this street. The site of the archbishop’s palace is now occupied by the Archdiocese of Manila’s archbishop’s residence and chancery. The north end of Arzobispo was named Audiencia because it passed by the building of the Real Audiencia. Cabildo was named after the city council or cabildo, which had its session hall along the street. The session hall was also called Ayuntamiento or city hall. The 19th-century cabildo was destroyed during World War II and has recently been restored.

Magallanes is named after Ferdinand Magellan. Solana, formerly known as Fonda, is probably named in honor of Governor Urbiztondo, the Marques de la Solana. Legazpi/San Juan de Dios St honors Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, who was the founder of Spanish Manila and first governor general of the Philippines. Its southeastern section was named after the hospital run by the Brothers of San Juan de Dios. The street was formerly known as Bomba, which can mean either pump or bomb.
Escuela is named after an unknown school. Letran, formerly Cerrada, is named after Colegio de San Juan de Letrán.

These are the roads that run perpendicular to the northwest and southeast axis of the city: Almacenes, presently Maestranza, is a short stretch of road that continues the perimeter road Muralla, near Plaza Militar. It is named for the real almacenes or the royal storehouses that stood inside and outside the walls, beside the Pasig River. The street led to a small gate called Almacenes that opened to the Pasig. The storehouses expanded to the casamata or vaulted chambers of the Maestranza wall, the thickest part of the Intramuros curtain wall. Maestranza has been restored, after it was deliberately demolished around 1905 to allow easy access to the wharfs along the Pasig.

Santa Clara is named after the Real Monasterio de Santa Clara, a convent of contemplative Franciscan nuns, founded by Sor Geronima Asuncion in 1621. Aduana, referred to the Aduana or Custom house at the northeastern end of the street, built in the neoclassical style of the 19th century. The Aduana building also housed the Intendencia or city management office and was the alternate name given to the building. The street is presently known as Andres Soriano Jr, after the industrialist and entrepreneur who founded San Miguel Corporation.

Postigo, formerly Cruzadas (Crusades), led to the postigo or postern gate and connects with Calle Santo Tomas. It was through this road and gate that Dr Jose P. Rizal passed on the way to his execution in Bagumbayan on 30 Dec 1896. Santo Tomas, the eastern end of Postigo, terminated at the Universidad de Santo Tomas.

Beaterio is named after the Beaterio de Santa Catalina. Anda honors Simon de Anda who organized the resistance during the British occupation of Manila (1762-64) and functioned as acting governor-general, while on exile in Bulacan. San Francisco is named after the Franciscan convent and church. Santa Potenciana is named after the patroness of Manila and a college for girls dedicated to her; the western end of this street is called San Agustin.

Novales is named after Capitan Andres Novales. Victoria is named after the 85-ton vessel used by Sebastian Elcano to circumnavigate the globe. Gen Douglas MacArthur built his headquarters at the western end of Victoria, giving it the address No 1 Victoria.

San Jose, named after the Colegio de San Jose, disappeared from the map, when the Jesuits petitioned the city to close the street and incorporate it as part of two adjacent compounds owned by the Jesuits. This made access to and from the Colegio de San Ignacio and Colegio de San Jose more convenient.

Maleçon was a road built outside the walls, along the shore, and beyond the moat beginning at the mouth of the Pasig, and ending in a half-moon turn called Luneta. Part of the road has become Bonifacio Drive and Padre Burgos Ave.

Plazas. Integral to the Renaissance-inspired colonial plans were plazas. These served as green areas for the city and as outdoor meeting places. The two largest plazas were: Plaza Militar, later called Plaza Moriones, and the Plaza Mayor. Located in front and southeast of Fort Santiago, Plaza Militar was used for military drills. Its perimeter was defined by the walls of the city and Almacenes or the royal storehouses and the Audiencia building. Inside Fort Santiago was Plaza de Armas, used for assembling troops as they changed guards for the walls of the fort and city.

Plaza Mayor stood in front of the Manila Cathedral. Around it were the most important buildings of the colonial era, the Cathedral, the Palacio del Gobernador, the Ayuntamiento, and the Real Audiencia. In 1824, a monument to Carlos IV was erected in the plaza to honor him for sending vaccines to control the spread of cholera in the 19th century. Bullfights and theatrical productions were held at the Plaza Mayor on several occasions. Plaza Mayor was renamed Plaza Roma to honor Pope Paul VI on his visit to the Philippines in 1970.

Other minor plazas were located in front or near the principal buildings, like churches and educational institutions. Universidad de Santo Tomas (UST) had its own small plaza, where the statue honoring Abp Miguel de Benavides, founder of the Santo Tomas, used to stand. The statue is now in the Sampaloc campus of UST. Plaza Sampalucan, also known as Plaza de Santa Isabel, is presently the site of Memorare, a memorial to Intramuros’s war victims.

Fortification. Fuerza de Santiago or Fort Santiago was the military fortification attached to the walled city. Built at the site of Rajah Sulayman’s fortified palisade, the site was captured by the invading troops led by Miguel Lopez de Legazpi in 1571.
